JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 14.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 2, 1914.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

STUDENT MISSIONARY MEETING

W. VA. GRADUATES ORGANIZE

STUDENT COUNCIL AT WORK

"PREP" MEN EASY FOR VARSITY

Unique Gathering of All University Men
Will Be Held Thursday to Discuss
Y. M. C. A. Problems.

Baby Alumni Association in Splendid
Health—First Banquet to Be
Held on February 22.

Arranges to Keep in Touch With Preparatory Schools —Takes First
Step in Regard to Hazing.

City-Poly Combination Outclassed by
Hopkins Athletes —New Cage
Record for the Half.

The Missionary Committee of the
Young Men's Christian Association
has planned a mass-meeting of students for Thursday night, in Levering Hall, to consider the missionary
Program of the Association.
The meeting will be unique, in
that, aside from the Young Men's
Christian Association reception in
the fall, it will be the first general
night meeting of students to consider any branch of religious endeavor.
The speakers and topics will be:
W. D. Sutton, '14, "The Recent
Student Volunteer Convention at
Kansas City"; Myron Bagley, '16,
The Advantages of Attendance
of the Eaglesmere Summer Conference"; Guy T. 0. Hollyday,
"The Missionary Offering from
Johns Hopkins"; Dr. Heckleman,
who is accompanying Dr. Sato on
his lecture tour, and who is a missionary from Japan; Rev. William
Levering De Vries, A.B. '88, fellow in Greek '90-'01, Ph.D. '92,
canon of Washington Cathedral,
a founder and one of the first officers of the Johns Hopkins Y. M.
C. A., author of the University ode,
and a former cheer-leader, will talk
on "The Call to Service in the Mission Field."
. Other speakers may be included
In. the program, but the meeting
will be of short duration.
After the talks, all men who are
sufficiently interested to become a
member of a mission study group,
will be asked to confer for five
minutes with the leaders of the
courses. Mr. W. D. Sutton and
Mr. A. K. Barton will have a class
on China for the freshmen and
others desiring to study "the newborn republic." Dr. Humpheries of the Grace and St. Peter's P. E.
Church will deal with South American problems. This class is for
sophomores. The . juniors will
study the Moslem world under the
leadership of Mr. H. M. Wagner.
The Missionary Committee for
this year is made up of A. K. Barton,.'14, chairman; Myron E. Bagley, '16, sub-chairman, Publicity
and Enrollment Committee; W. D.
Sutton, '14, sub-chairman, Missionary Meetings Committee; G. T. 0.
Hollyday, '14, sub-chairman, Missionary Offering Committee; E.
Deems, '15, sub-chairman, Missionary Library Committee; J. C. Branham, 'is, sub-chairman, Mission
Study Committee; Vernon Lynch,
'14, sub-chairman, Mission Boards
Committee.

The fact that the Hopkins idea
is spreading, and that its graduates
in different parts of the country
desire to combine, was clearly illustrated by the recent formation of the
Johns Hopkins Alumni Association
of West Virginia. The members
are mostly members of the faculty
of the West Virginia University,
and comprise some of the most important educators of the State. The
president of the Association is Dr.
A. M. Reese, A.B. '92; Ph.D. '00,
who is now professor of zoology
at the West Virginia University,
and the secretary-treasurer is Dr.
W. D. Price, Jr., Ph.D. '1 1. instructor in geology at the West Virginia University and paleontologist
of the West Virginia Geological
Survey. The remaining members
are: Dr. 0. P. Chitwood, Ph.D.
'05, professor of European history
at the West Virginia University;
Dr. J. A. Eiesland, Ph.D. '98, professor of mathematics at the West
Virginia University; Dr. J. M. Callahan, Ph.D. 97, professor of history and political science; Rev. F.
F. Briggs, a Baptist minister; Mr.
B. H. Hite, fellow in chemistry
here from 1893 to 1895, now professor of agricultural chemistry at
the West Virginia University, and
chief chemist of the West Virginia
Geological Survey; Dr. J. E. Hodgson, Ph.D. '09, associate porfessor
of mathematics; Dr. J. N. Simpson.
M.D.'02, professor of anatomy and
physiology, and Mr. Walter South,
who attended courses at the Hopkins Medical School for several
years and is now connected with the
Randall Gas and Water Company
of Morgantown, W. Va.
It can be seen that this infant is
now in surprisingly good health,
and that if its growth continues in
comparison, it will soon • rank
among the leading alumni associations of the University.

At the last meeting of THE NEwsLETTER Board was put to vote a
suggestion of the Student Council
that the Board donate for the good
of the University a certain number
of copies of the paper to be distributed among the graduating
classes of the preparatory schools
around Baltimore. After favorable
discussion the motion was passed
that a hundred copies of the three
most important issues of the year
be given the Student Council for
distribution in the following manner: a copy should be sent to every
member of the graduating class
of the smaller preparatory schools;
to the class officers of the graduating students of the larger schools.
The Council has already set to
work to collect the names of the
men to whom THE NEWS-LETTER
is to be sent.
In this way it is hoped that the
students in the secondary institutions will have a better opportunity
to learn of the advantages of the
different departments of the University, and especially of the excellent progress which the Technical School is making and the manifold chances that it offers.
Ever since the resolution offered
by Bagley in November, asking
that the Student Council consider
methods of regulating the hazing
at the University, the Council has
been hard at work trying to devise
certain changes which would improve the situation. The difficulty
is to retain the advantages which
would be resultant from a proper
application of the better principles
lying at the base of college hazing.
There is undoubtedly involyed a
valuable factor of class spirit, and
also a laudable (though at present
misguided) endeavor to direct the
freshman in the path whither he
should go. To preserve the saner
parts of the latter, the Student

In the second practice for the
track-meet men, held last Saturday
night, in which City College and
Polytechnic combined their forces
against the Hopkins athletes, the
"Prep" School boys proved no
match for the Collegians, who piled
up a score of 66 points to 25. As
the contest was only a practice one,
many of the Johns Hopkins University men were entered in events
with which they were not familiar,
but the results show that they were
equal to the test. The outcome of
the first race (the 30-yard dash)
was rather discouraging as a beginning for Hopkins. Three men
from each side qualified for the
finals, and after several false starts.
when the gun was fired, the three
"Prep" School men had a lead of
over a yard, and Wagner, (J. H.
U.) was left on his marks. The
"Prep" School boys finished one,
two, three, as they had started, the
time being four seconds.. However,
things were reversed in the 30-yard
hurdles, in which only one B. C. C.
man reached the finals, and he
failed to place. The event was won
by Tappan, Penniman and Randall.
all J. H. U., in the order named,
in four and one-fifth seconds.
The only event in which a cage
• record was disturbed was the 88oyard run. "Poly" had counted
upon their crack half-miler, Chipman, to win this race, but after
holding a good lead for six laps,
Catlin (J. H. U.), who had kept
a more steady pace, easily passed
him, and broke the tape in two
minutes 12*g seconds, lowering
Uhler's record of a week before by
one second. The race was run in
beautiful form, and the record will
probably stand for a long time.
The next event, the 220-yard dash,
was a walk-away for Wells and
Gayley, both Hopkins men, who
finished within a couple of yards
5 seconds.
of each other, in 28/
Uhler ran a fine race in the 440, in
59 seconds, followed closely by
Wagner. "Poly" men took third
in both these events.
The mile run, which is always an
interesting race, because of its prolonged uncertainty, was a close
fight to the very end. F. Hall
(J. H. U.) .took the lead with the
gun, and held it until the fourteenth
lap of the eighteen. Then Bierau,
the crack man of Baltimore City
College, starting his sprint too soon,
took the lead for a few seconds,

M. Fernand Baldensperger, professor of comparative literature at
the University of Paris, will deliver
a lecture at five o'clock Wednesday
in McCoy Hall on "French Enthusiasm About America During the
Period from 1770-1789." Much •
has already been said and written
about our relations with France
during the troublous times of the
two epoch-making revolutions, that
of America against England, and
that of the French peasantry against
the nobility. It is well known that
France responded nobly to our appeal for foreign assistance in 1778,
and it is also common knowledge
that Washington felt constrained
to keep this country neutral during
the French Revolution. The French
were naturally disappointed, and
it will be of interest to hear the
point of view of the other side, and
what M. Baldensperger will have
to say about our change of attitude
in 1778 and 1789.

Free Scholarships.
An unlimited number of free
scholarships bearing cash values of
from $250 to $1,0oo is offered to
Hopkins men by the Review of Reviews Company, New York city.
In the past five years over one thousand students from different colleges have won these scholarships.
They are open to all American college men and are not,won by competitive eXaminations, but for work
done during spare time and in the
summer. The work is dignified and
pleasant, and is under the direction
of Mr. H. W. Frey, who in I9o9
won such a scholarship at Hopkins.
He writes that, working in spare
time, he cleared $250 above expenses.
President Woodrow Wilson, formerly head of Princeton, together
with five other college presidents,
has endorsed this scholarship plan.
"A certificate of such endorsement," says the bureau, "is placed
in the hands of every student whose
application for enrollment as a
scholarship candidate is accepted."
Mr. Frey adds that he would especially like to get in touch with
some live Hopkins men who will
work this plan in Baltimore. A
postcard to the Review of Reviews'
Scholarship Fund, 30 Irving Place,
New York city, will secure full particulars about these scholarships.

STATES RIGHTS THE ISSUE

DR. SATO LECTURES ON JAPAN

Dr. Adams' Second Civil War Lecture
Discusses the Issues of Politics
Preceding the Conflict.

Distinguished Alumnus is Delivering a
Course of Six Talks as Exchange
Lecturer at McCoy Hall.

That the doctrines of States rights
secession and nullification, the leading political issues preceding the
Civil War, were not peculiar to the
South, but were practiced at different times in all parts of the
Union previous to the war, was the
main feature of Dr. Charles Francis Adams' second lecture, "The
Pitfall of a Divided Sovereignty,"
delivered last Tuesday before an
unusually large attendance in McCoy Hall.
Dr. Adams, at the beginning of
his talk, asserted that the nationality of the United States was a development, the seed of which was
sown in 1714, and did not bear perfect fruit until "Appomattox Day,"
1865. With this theme, the distinguished historian said that the hatred between the individual American colonies was bitter before and
after the Revolution, that the Articles of Confederation and later
the Constitution were regarded at
at the time as merely expedients
adopted to secure more concerted
strength in warfare.
He showed them that sovereignty
in relation to the States and the
Federal Government was left undecided and uncertain even in the
minds of the framers of the Constitution, and that the question was
brought up again and again by
declarations of sovereignty, now by
a Northern State, now by a Southern State.
The lecturer continued in effect:
"The economic system founded on
slavery ill the South was the cause
for that section's holding to its
State rights belief after the North
had cast its own aside. Foreign
immigration, turned away from the
great South by the institution of
slave labor, was naturally directed
towards the North and West, and
this new element, together with the
growth of rapid communication,
served to unify the non-slavery
States, and caused them to attribute
more power to the government at
Washington' than formerly. So
the South, holding to its old views,
and the North having grown away
from them, a breach was inevitable." Dr. Adams considers the
closing of this breach—the end of
the Civil War—the climax of the
development of our nationality.
In his next lecture, "King Cotton," Dr. Adams will enlarge upon
a conclusion of his own, arrived at
by him after exhaustive original research in England and elsewhere,
that the Civil War was decided by
the Lancashire cotton spinners in
England, and not on the bloody battlefields of the war. This lecture is
to be given on Thursday, February 5.

Bearing a message of national
good will from his country to ours,
Dr. Shosuke Sato, Ph.D., dean of
the College of Agriculture at Sapporo, Japan, exchange lecturer for
this year, delivered three lectures
on Monday, Wednesday and Friday
of last week.
In treating his topics, which dealt
with the social and political life
and history of Japan, Dr. Sato
spoke authoritatively, and his hearers gained from him a comprehensive idea of the changes in form the
Japanese Government has undergone in the last half century, and
of 'the present rapid progress being made in the betterment of economic conditions.
Perhaps the lecture of most personal interest to Hopkins students
was the first, in which Dr. Sato
expressed his pleasure at being
once more within the walls of his
alma mater, and paid high tribute
to the faculty, past and present.
Proceeding to his subject, he
sketched the new Japanese trade
with other countries and the development of the functions of government, as embodied in the transition,"From Old Feudalism to Modern Imperialism."
Wednesday the subject was "So.cial Changes and Reforms Since
the Restoration," while on Friday
Dr. Sato told of "Local Autonomy
and Constitutional Government in
Japan." The speaker is a scholar
of the highest attainment.
He will continue the course on
Monday, Tuesday and Friday of
this week.

is managing editor for this issue.
We Need A Boosters' Committee.

THE NEWS-LETTER has long considered the advisability of a committee whose business it will be to
set before prospective students the
academic, athletic, and social advantages of Johns Hopkins. In
other words, we want a live "boost'ers' committee." No college or
university is, successful in extracurriculum activities with a poor
body of students to draw from. To
keep up and to better the college
activities of Johns Hopkins we
must increase the number and the
calibre of the men in the undergraduate department.
The trend of the present day is

for men to go to colleges where the
so-called "college life" abounds.
Johns Hopkins is often erroneously
thought to be totally lacking in college life. By many of the "prep"
schools we are considered "nothing but a day school." They can't
see "why a man wants to go to
Hopkins." This is, for us, a rather

unhealthy state of mind.
In academic attractions, Hopkins
takes first rank. Perhaps the halo
of the medical and graduate departments is reflected on the undergraduate. But as to scholarship, we
need no advertising.
The athletic management, this
year, instituted an admirable plan
to interest the school boys of Baltimore in Hopkins athletics. Tickets
were sent to the schools of the city,
which admit the holder to the
games at half price. This is a
broad and far-sighted policy.
It is true, however, that too little
effort is made to get good athletes
to come here. Some enthusiast may

occasionaly get busy and land a
good focitball player, but as to
rigorous, earnest efforts to get athletes, there are none. We should
"campaign" every player, on every
local school and boarding-school
team near Baltimore.
But it is particularly the nonathletic activities that a committee
should work for what they are
worth. Men should be brought to
the concerts of the Musical Clubs,
or perhaps to the cotillons. The college publications should be more
widely circulated among the preparatory schools. (THE NEWS-LETTER has already planned greatly to
enlarge its school circulation.)
Many are the ways by which an
imaginative committee could demonstrate to sub-freshmen the frolics
and gayeties of the J. H. U.
The introduction of the Honor
System was once thought impossible. The Student Council and 'the
men behind the movement should
be gratefully remembered for the
change they have wrought in the
college atmosphere. By some such
committee as we have proposed,
well selected and judiciously prod.ded, the Council can do a valuable
service to the University.
We hope for the appointment of
such a committee.

Austrian Economist to Lecture.

Prof. Josef Schumpeter, professor of political economy in the University of Graz, and Austrian exchange lecturer for 1914, will deliver a series of three lectures before the Economic Seminary at nine
o'clock on Monday, Tuesday and
Wednesday mornings of this week.
The general subject of these lectures will be "The, Fundamental
Concepts of Eco'nomics."
Professor Schumpeter, although
only thirty years old, is already one
of the leading European economists.
Professor Schumpeter's system
of economic theory is develoned in
his two books, "Content and Essentials of Theoretical Political
Economy" and "Theory of Economic Development." In addition
he has published a number of im'portant pamphlets and papers.
He has recently turned his attention to sociology, and it is very
probable that he will emphasize the
social concepts of economics in his
lectures. He will speak in English.

Actor to Lecture on Shakespeare.

will probably be of great interest to a number of the students
to learn that Mr. F. R. Benson, the
head of the Stratford-Upon-Avon
Players, who are here this week
under an engagement with the
Academy of Music, will visit the
University next Thursday to speak
to the students. The meeting will
be held in the Donovan Room at
four o'clock, February 5. On account of the limited capacity of the
room, the public will not be invited
to this talk by Mr. Benson. It is
hoped that the students will show
enough interest in the speech and
the speaker to fill the room. Mr.
Benson is not only an actor, but
an artist and a man of letters. He
has had charge of the production
of Shakespearian plays for over a
quarter of a century, and it should
prove a rare opportunity to be thus
able to hear him speak. His company is engaged in giving the plays
of Shakespeare, not to earn their
salaries, for they come from the
only endowed English theatre in
the world. They give the plays for
the sake of art, and Mr. Benson
ought, therefore, to be specially
fitted to speak to the students upon
something that they almost to a
man should be and are interested
in. Remember: Thursday, at four,
Donovan Room.

Dear Sir—I want to object strenuously, through your columns, to
the inconsiderate manner in which
the date of the second cotillon has
been chosen by the Board of Governors. The evening of February
27 has been announced and has.subsequently been seen to be the third
day of Lent. Being unacquainted
with this fact, the Board engaged
the services of a popular orchestra,
or better a popular orchestra leader,
for February 27, and the Board
sublimely gives this fact as the only
reason for not •changing the date.
Now, when confronted with the
statement of the popular orchestra
leader himself that he has too much
work (which would indicate that
he would not hesitate to let the
Board break its engagement for
the disputed date), the Board replies that the cotillon would not be
a success without his music.
Some people follow this popular
orchestra leader about from dance
to dance, it is true, for his good
music; and it is often noticeable,
too, that these same people in their
last extremity -fall back upon the
popular orchestra leader for a subject of conversation between dances.
If other music were supplied and
the date moved forward, perhaps
these people, being at a loss, might

DEBATE FOR THE PEACE CONTEST

Schedule to Include Many Good Trips
The Large Number of Candidates
Promises a Strong Team.

Chairman of Grotius Society Peace Contest Committee Announces that
Date Has Been Selected.

For more than a week the baseball squad, under the watchful eye
of Coach Hooper, has been working out in the cage, and a great
deal of promising material has
come to light. Of last year's nine,
Captain Porter, Pieper, Wilson,
Sylvester, Dorsey, Webster, Williams, Bagley, Rice and McDowell
are out, while a number of new
men look good. Worthington, last
year captain of Princeton, will be
a great addition to the infield.
Among the other new candidates
are Gorman, Stevenson, Cockey,
Stollenwerck, Triesler, Bowers, Diffendorf, Meekins, Chesley, Hall,
Hicks, Conn, Mudge, Pitt, Campbell, Richardson, Tinges and Hoffman. The schedule, as recently announced by Manager Hilgartner, is
as follows:
March 21—Rock Hill College at
Ellicott City.
March 28—Princeton at Princeton.
April 4—Maryland Agricultural
College at Homewood.
April 11—Holy Cross College at
Homewood.
April 14—University of Virginia
at Charlottesville.
April 15—Navy at AnnaPolis.
April 18—Virginia Military Academy at Homewood.
April 25—Western Maryland College at Homewood.
May 2 — Delaware College at
Newark, Del.
May 9—Swarthmore at Swarthmore.
May i6—St. Johns at Homewood.

Lectures on Hydro-Electric Development.

"PREP" MEN EASY FOR VARSITY

A meeting of much interest to
technical students was held in the
Physical Laboratory last Thursday
night. It was arranged and conducted in co-operation by the Department of Engineering of the
University, the American Institute
of Electrical Engineers, Baltimore
section, and the Watson Electric
Light Association, Baltimore Consolidated section.
Two papers by eminent authorities were presented on waterpower development in the Middle
West. Both were fully illustrated
by lantern slides.
Mr. A. S. Loizeaux, electrical
engineer of the Gas and Electric
Company, read the paper "Hydraulic Plant of the Mississippi River
Power Company at Keokuk, Iowa,"
by Mr. Walter Goodenough; while
Mr. T. 0. Kennedy's paper on
"The Ozark Power and Water
Company's Development on the
White River, near Forsythe, Mo.,"
was read by Mr. J. C. Lathrop,
designing engineer of the same
Company.
As announced in THE NEWSLETTER last week, the February
meetings of the Engineering Society will be held on Monday the
ninth at 4.30 P. M., at which time
Dr. Gilpin will speak on "The

The Missionary Committee of the
Young Men's Christian Association
has planned a mass-meeting of students for Thursday night, in Levering Hall, to consider the missionary
Program of the Association.
The meeting will be unique, in
that, aside from the Young Men's
Christian Association reception in
the fall, it will be the first general
night meeting of students to consider any branch of religious endeavor.
The speakers and topics will be:
W. D. Sutton, '14, "The Recent
Student Volunteer Convention at
Kansas City"; Myron Bagley, '16,
The Advantages of Attendance
of the Eaglesmere Summer Conference"; Guy T. 0. Hollyday,
"The Missionary Offering from
Johns Hopkins"; Dr. Heckleman,
who is accompanying Dr. Sato on
his lecture tour, and who is a missionary from Japan; Rev. William
Levering De Vries, A.B. '88, fellow in Greek '90-'01, Ph.D. '92,
canon of Washington Cathedral,
a founder and one of the first officers of the Johns Hopkins Y. M.
C. A., author of the University ode,
and a former cheer-leader, will talk
on "The Call to Service in the Mission Field."
. Other speakers may be included
In. the program, but the meeting
will be of short duration.
After the talks, all men who are
sufficiently interested to become a
member of a mission study group,
will be asked to confer for five
minutes with the leaders of the
courses. Mr. W. D. Sutton and
Mr. A. K. Barton will have a class
on China for the freshmen and
others desiring to study "the newborn republic." Dr. Humpheries of the Grace and St. Peter's P. E.
Church will deal with South American problems. This class is for
sophomores. The . juniors will
study the Moslem world under the
leadership of Mr. H. M. Wagner.
The Missionary Committee for
this year is made up of A. K. Barton,.'14, chairman; Myron E. Bagley, '16, sub-chairman, Publicity
and Enrollment Committee; W. D.
Sutton, '14, sub-chairman, Missionary Meetings Committee; G. T. 0.
Hollyday, '14, sub-chairman, Missionary Offering Committee; E.
Deems, '15, sub-chairman, Missionary Library Committee; J. C. Branham, 'is, sub-chairman, Mission
Study Committee; Vernon Lynch,
'14, sub-chairman, Mission Boards
Committee.

The fact that the Hopkins idea
is spreading, and that its graduates
in different parts of the country
desire to combine, was clearly illustrated by the recent formation of the
Johns Hopkins Alumni Association
of West Virginia. The members
are mostly members of the faculty
of the West Virginia University,
and comprise some of the most important educators of the State. The
president of the Association is Dr.
A. M. Reese, A.B. '92; Ph.D. '00,
who is now professor of zoology
at the West Virginia University,
and the secretary-treasurer is Dr.
W. D. Price, Jr., Ph.D. '1 1. instructor in geology at the West Virginia University and paleontologist
of the West Virginia Geological
Survey. The remaining members
are: Dr. 0. P. Chitwood, Ph.D.
'05, professor of European history
at the West Virginia University;
Dr. J. A. Eiesland, Ph.D. '98, professor of mathematics at the West
Virginia University; Dr. J. M. Callahan, Ph.D. 97, professor of history and political science; Rev. F.
F. Briggs, a Baptist minister; Mr.
B. H. Hite, fellow in chemistry
here from 1893 to 1895, now professor of agricultural chemistry at
the West Virginia University, and
chief chemist of the West Virginia
Geological Survey; Dr. J. E. Hodgson, Ph.D. '09, associate porfessor
of mathematics; Dr. J. N. Simpson.
M.D.'02, professor of anatomy and
physiology, and Mr. Walter South,
who attended courses at the Hopkins Medical School for several
years and is now connected with the
Randall Gas and Water Company
of Morgantown, W. Va.
It can be seen that this infant is
now in surprisingly good health,
and that if its growth continues in
comparison, it will soon • rank
among the leading alumni associations of the University.

M. Fernand Baldensperger, professor of comparative literature at
the University of Paris, will deliver
a lecture at five o'clock Wednesday
in McCoy Hall on "French Enthusiasm About America During the
Period from 1770-1789." Much •
has already been said and written
about our relations with France
during the troublous times of the
two epoch-making revolutions, that
of America against England, and
that of the French peasantry against
the nobility. It is well known that
France responded nobly to our appeal for foreign assistance in 1778,
and it is also common knowledge
that Washington felt constrained
to keep this country neutral during
the French Revolution. The French
were naturally disappointed, and
it will be of interest to hear the
point of view of the other side, and
what M. Baldensperger will have
to say about our change of attitude
in 1778 and 1789.

Free Scholarships.
An unlimited number of free
scholarships bearing cash values of
from $250 to $1,0oo is offered to
Hopkins men by the Review of Reviews Company, New York city.
In the past five years over one thousand students from different colleges have won these scholarships.
They are open to all American college men and are not,won by competitive eXaminations, but for work
done during spare time and in the
summer. The work is dignified and
pleasant, and is under the direction
of Mr. H. W. Frey, who in I9o9
won such a scholarship at Hopkins.
He writes that, working in spare
time, he cleared $250 above expenses.
President Woodrow Wilson, formerly head of Princeton, together
with five other college presidents,
has endorsed this scholarship plan.
"A certificate of such endorsement," says the bureau, "is placed
in the hands of every student whose
application for enrollment as a
scholarship candidate is accepted."
Mr. Frey adds that he would especially like to get in touch with
some live Hopkins men who will
work this plan in Baltimore. A
postcard to the Review of Reviews'
Scholarship Fund, 30 Irving Place,
New York city, will secure full particulars about these scholarships.

STATES RIGHTS THE ISSUE

DR. SATO LECTURES ON JAPAN

Dr. Adams' Second Civil War Lecture
Discusses the Issues of Politics
Preceding the Conflict.

Distinguished Alumnus is Delivering a
Course of Six Talks as Exchange
Lecturer at McCoy Hall.

That the doctrines of States rights
secession and nullification, the leading political issues preceding the
Civil War, were not peculiar to the
South, but were practiced at different times in all parts of the
Union previous to the war, was the
main feature of Dr. Charles Francis Adams' second lecture, "The
Pitfall of a Divided Sovereignty,"
delivered last Tuesday before an
unusually large attendance in McCoy Hall.
Dr. Adams, at the beginning of
his talk, asserted that the nationality of the United States was a development, the seed of which was
sown in 1714, and did not bear perfect fruit until "Appomattox Day,"
1865. With this theme, the distinguished historian said that the hatred between the individual American colonies was bitter before and
after the Revolution, that the Articles of Confederation and later
the Constitution were regarded at
at the time as merely expedients
adopted to secure more concerted
strength in warfare.
He showed them that sovereignty
in relation to the States and the
Federal Government was left undecided and uncertain even in the
minds of the framers of the Constitution, and that the question was
brought up again and again by
declarations of sovereignty, now by
a Northern State, now by a Southern State.
The lecturer continued in effect:
"The economic system founded on
slavery ill the South was the cause
for that section's holding to its
State rights belief after the North
had cast its own aside. Foreign
immigration, turned away from the
great South by the institution of
slave labor, was naturally directed
towards the North and West, and
this new element, together with the
growth of rapid communication,
served to unify the non-slavery
States, and caused them to attribute
more power to the government at
Washington' than formerly. So
the South, holding to its old views,
and the North having grown away
from them, a breach was inevitable." Dr. Adams considers the
closing of this breach—the end of
the Civil War—the climax of the
development of our nationality.
In his next lecture, "King Cotton," Dr. Adams will enlarge upon
a conclusion of his own, arrived at
by him after exhaustive original research in England and elsewhere,
that the Civil War was decided by
the Lancashire cotton spinners in
England, and not on the bloody battlefields of the war. This lecture is
to be given on Thursday, February 5.

Bearing a message of national
good will from his country to ours,
Dr. Shosuke Sato, Ph.D., dean of
the College of Agriculture at Sapporo, Japan, exchange lecturer for
this year, delivered three lectures
on Monday, Wednesday and Friday
of last week.
In treating his topics, which dealt
with the social and political life
and history of Japan, Dr. Sato
spoke authoritatively, and his hearers gained from him a comprehensive idea of the changes in form the
Japanese Government has undergone in the last half century, and
of 'the present rapid progress being made in the betterment of economic conditions.
Perhaps the lecture of most personal interest to Hopkins students
was the first, in which Dr. Sato
expressed his pleasure at being
once more within the walls of his
alma mater, and paid high tribute
to the faculty, past and present.
Proceeding to his subject, he
sketched the new Japanese trade
with other countries and the development of the functions of government, as embodied in the transition,"From Old Feudalism to Modern Imperialism."
Wednesday the subject was "So.cial Changes and Reforms Since
the Restoration," while on Friday
Dr. Sato told of "Local Autonomy
and Constitutional Government in
Japan." The speaker is a scholar
of the highest attainment.
He will continue the course on
Monday, Tuesday and Friday of
this week.

We Need A Boosters' Committee.

THE NEWS-LETTER has long considered the advisability of a committee whose business it will be to
set before prospective students the
academic, athletic, and social advantages of Johns Hopkins. In
other words, we want a live "boost'ers' committee." No college or
university is, successful in extracurriculum activities with a poor
body of students to draw from. To
keep up and to better the college
activities of Johns Hopkins we
must increase the number and the
calibre of the men in the undergraduate department.
The trend of the present day is

for men to go to colleges where the
so-called "college life" abounds.
Johns Hopkins is often erroneously
thought to be totally lacking in college life. By many of the "prep"
schools we are considered "nothing but a day school." They can't
see "why a man wants to go to
Hopkins." This is, for us, a rather

unhealthy state of mind.
In academic attractions, Hopkins
takes first rank. Perhaps the halo
of the medical and graduate departments is reflected on the undergraduate. But as to scholarship, we
need no advertising.
The athletic management, this
year, instituted an admirable plan
to interest the school boys of Baltimore in Hopkins athletics. Tickets
were sent to the schools of the city,
which admit the holder to the
games at half price. This is a
broad and far-sighted policy.
It is true, however, that too little
effort is made to get good athletes
to come here. Some enthusiast may

occasionaly get busy and land a
good focitball player, but as to
rigorous, earnest efforts to get athletes, there are none. We should
"campaign" every player, on every
local school and boarding-school
team near Baltimore.
But it is particularly the nonathletic activities that a committee
should work for what they are
worth. Men should be brought to
the concerts of the Musical Clubs,
or perhaps to the cotillons. The college publications should be more
widely circulated among the preparatory schools. (THE NEWS-LETTER has already planned greatly to
enlarge its school circulation.)
Many are the ways by which an
imaginative committee could demonstrate to sub-freshmen the frolics
and gayeties of the J. H. U.
The introduction of the Honor
System was once thought impossible. The Student Council and 'the
men behind the movement should
be gratefully remembered for the
change they have wrought in the
college atmosphere. By some such
committee as we have proposed,
well selected and judiciously prod.ded, the Council can do a valuable
service to the University.
We hope for the appointment of
such a committee.

Austrian Economist to Lecture.

Prof. Josef Schumpeter, professor of political economy in the University of Graz, and Austrian exchange lecturer for 1914, will deliver a series of three lectures before the Economic Seminary at nine
o'clock on Monday, Tuesday and
Wednesday mornings of this week.
The general subject of these lectures will be "The, Fundamental
Concepts of Eco'nomics."
Professor Schumpeter, although
only thirty years old, is already one
of the leading European economists.
Professor Schumpeter's system
of economic theory is develoned in
his two books, "Content and Essentials of Theoretical Political
Economy" and "Theory of Economic Development." In addition
he has published a number of im'portant pamphlets and papers.
He has recently turned his attention to sociology, and it is very
probable that he will emphasize the
social concepts of economics in his
lectures. He will speak in English.

Actor to Lecture on Shakespeare.

will probably be of great interest to a number of the students
to learn that Mr. F. R. Benson, the
head of the Stratford-Upon-Avon
Players, who are here this week
under an engagement with the
Academy of Music, will visit the
University next Thursday to speak
to the students. The meeting will
be held in the Donovan Room at
four o'clock, February 5. On account of the limited capacity of the
room, the public will not be invited
to this talk by Mr. Benson. It is
hoped that the students will show
enough interest in the speech and
the speaker to fill the room. Mr.
Benson is not only an actor, but
an artist and a man of letters. He
has had charge of the production
of Shakespearian plays for over a
quarter of a century, and it should
prove a rare opportunity to be thus
able to hear him speak. His company is engaged in giving the plays
of Shakespeare, not to earn their
salaries, for they come from the
only endowed English theatre in
the world. They give the plays for
the sake of art, and Mr. Benson
ought, therefore, to be specially
fitted to speak to the students upon
something that they almost to a
man should be and are interested
in. Remember: Thursday, at four,
Donovan Room.

Dear Sir—I want to object strenuously, through your columns, to
the inconsiderate manner in which
the date of the second cotillon has
been chosen by the Board of Governors. The evening of February
27 has been announced and has.subsequently been seen to be the third
day of Lent. Being unacquainted
with this fact, the Board engaged
the services of a popular orchestra,
or better a popular orchestra leader,
for February 27, and the Board
sublimely gives this fact as the only
reason for not •changing the date.
Now, when confronted with the
statement of the popular orchestra
leader himself that he has too much
work (which would indicate that
he would not hesitate to let the
Board break its engagement for
the disputed date), the Board replies that the cotillon would not be
a success without his music.
Some people follow this popular
orchestra leader about from dance
to dance, it is true, for his good
music; and it is often noticeable,
too, that these same people in their
last extremity -fall back upon the
popular orchestra leader for a subject of conversation between dances.

the date moved forward, perhaps
these people, being at a loss, might

Lectures on Hydro-Electric Development.

"PREP" MEN EASY FOR VARSITY

A meeting of much interest to
technical students was held in the
Physical Laboratory last Thursday
night. It was arranged and conducted in co-operation by the Department of Engineering of the
University, the American Institute
of Electrical Engineers, Baltimore
section, and the Watson Electric
Light Association, Baltimore Consolidated section.
Two papers by eminent authorities were presented on waterpower development in the Middle
West. Both were fully illustrated
by lantern slides.
Mr. A. S. Loizeaux, electrical
engineer of the Gas and Electric
Company, read the paper "Hydraulic Plant of the Mississippi River
Power Company at Keokuk, Iowa,"
by Mr. Walter Goodenough; while
Mr. T. 0. Kennedy's paper on
"The Ozark Power and Water
Company's Development on the
White River, near Forsythe, Mo.,"
was read by Mr. J. C. Lathrop,
designing engineer of the same
Company.
As announced in THE NEWSLETTER last week, the February
meetings of the Engineering Society will be held on Monday the
ninth at 4.30 P. M., at which time
Dr. Gilpin will speak on "The
Place of Chemistry in Envineering."

The three men ran close on each
others heels until the last lap, when
Hall came forward with a strong
spurt and beat out Catlin at the
finish by a few inches. The time
was only fair for the cage, g five
minutes eight and three-fifth seconds. In the shot-put the "Prep"
boys made the second of their two
only victories. Bangs (B. P. I.),
winner of the 30-yard dash, won
this event also with a put of 38 feet
4 inches. Sturgis, of City College,
took second, but both these men had
a considerable handicap over the
Hopkins representatives. In the
jumps all the honors went to Hopkins, except third in the high jump,
which was captured by Armiger
(B. P. I.).
The contest was concluded by
two relays, the first 800 yards, and
the second, 1,600 yards. The first,
Wells, Melamet, Thompson and
Gayley, easily won for Hopkins in
one minute 38*g seconds. In the
second the "Prep" school man took
the lead from the start, and Sutton
for Hopkins could only follow close
at his heels.
Although the City College and
Polytechnic men were working together, it is interesting to note that
B. P. I. made 17 points, while B.
C. C. made but 8. The Hopkins
men will now have a rest until the
Fifth Regiment Armory meet, two
weeks hence. Summary:

STUDENT COUNCIL AT WORK

705 N. HOWARD ST.

"Customer Must Be Pleased"
Our Motto

Council has asked the freshman
delegate to propose to his class the
appointment of a committee to draw
up certain "freshman regulations,"
which might be put into effect next
year with the support of the whole
student body. These regulations
are to be referred back to the Council for discussion in conjunction
with the committee which drew
them up.
It is rumored that the Council
has under consideration a novel
plan to provide a legitimate outlet
for interclass spirit; and that the
plan would probably be in shape
for announcement by next week.
